Episodes.Episode: Episode One - The Sea Of Death

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis lands on an island dominated by a huge pyramid. Ian is still wearing a silk Chinese jacket instead of his cardigan.

Dialogue.Line: Any radiation, Doctor?
No, nothing to speak of. The counter's hardly reading anything. Shall we take a look?
Pity you don't have colour television.
Oh, but I have.
Where is it, then?
Well, at the moment it's temporarily hors de combat.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They look at the scanner.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, look. That's the sea, isn't it?
Yes, and sand. Grandfather, I wonder where we are?
One thing's sure. We're not at Southend.
Grandfather, can we go and have a look? Can we?
Yes, I don't think, I don't see why not. There's nothing, no danger about. Come on. Let's go and have a look.
No.
What?
Well, I thought when you switched the scanner on, I thought I saw something move up there. Oh, probably just a shadow.
Well, let's go outside and have a look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Four torpedo-like things glide up to the beach. On closer inspection, they look like metal fish.

Dialogue.Line: It is the sea. It's beautiful.
Yes, absolutely calm. Not even a ripple.
It isn't frozen, is it?
No, impossible in this temperature. Besides, it's too warm.
Grandfather, do you think it's safe to go for a swim?
Oh, no, no. Not at the moment, child. However inviting that water looks, we don't know what sort of creatures might be lurking beneath its surface.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They explore the rocks, and don't see the frogman with flippers following them.

Dialogue.Line: It's so quiet.
Yes, it is. No birds or anything.
There's nothing growing.
I say, what do you make of this, Chesterton? Fascinating.
It's glass.
Yes, it is, isn't it. Yes. Glass instead of sand, eh? Intriguing, intriguing, my boy.
Do you think the sand turned into glass?
Or was the glass put here deliberately, and if so, why, hmm?
There's a lovely pool over here. If I can't swim, at least I can paddle.
(slipping and bumping into her, making her drop a shoe into the pool) Oh, sorry, Susan.
Never mind. I'll get it. You going to come in?
No.
No, Susan, don't!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He's spotted the shoe dissolving in the water.

Dialogue.Line: Ian, what is it?
Must be some sort of acid.
But it was so fast. It just seemed to dissolve.
And I was going to paddle in it.
It's all right, Susan. It's all right. Look, you've got some more shoes back at the ship, haven't you? Well, go and put them on. We'll wait here for you.
Here, you'd better take my boots.
I can't put those on. They're much too big for me.
Now, come on. It's better than cutting your feet open on this glass.
All right.
There.
I'm going to fill them up with sand anyway.
All right?
Yes.
They'll give you lovely corns, those will.
Seven league boots, hey?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Susan clumps off.

Dialogue.Line: Ian. This is a tidal pool.
Yes, I agree. Rather ties up with the glass beach, doesn't it.
Then everything out there is acid too. A sea of acid.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The frogman tries to get into the Tardis, then hides as Susan returns.

Dialogue.Line: Sea of acid. Astonishing. You know, in all my travels I've never come across anything like this before. However, Susan wasn't harmed, anyway.
She was a bit frightened of losing her shoes, but she's gone back to the ship for another pair.
Yes, and if you'd had your shoes on, my boy, you could have lent her hers. You mustn't get sloppy in your habits, you know. Good gracious.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He's seen the metal fish on the beach.

Dialogue.Line: It looks like a glass torpedo.
Or a one man submarine. It's certainly designed for going under the water.
Under acid, more likely.
Yes. I don't know if it's occurred to you, Doctor, but this means this place is inhabited.
Oh, yes, it has occurred to me. Let's see what it is. Help me get this top off.
Doctor!
Yes?
There's another one over here, and there's something inside it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Susan comes out of the Tardis in a fresh pair of pumps, and carrying Ian's boots, when she notices the imprint of a frogman's flipper in the sand.

Dialogue.Line: Grandfather!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She goes to follow the trail.

Dialogue.Line: See that crack along there? It's where the acid must have seeped in.
That's got it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The sub opens.

Dialogue.Line: Now, let's have a look at you.
Use that, use that.
Hmm? Oh, all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He uses the Doctor's walking stick to pull out a frogman's suit.

Dialogue.Line: It's a protective suit!
Yes, and whatever it was wore it, is similar to a human being, hmm?
Yes, but how did it get out? Seems to be perfectly intact.
I don't think it did get out. There's a tear in the material here.
You mean the acid got in. Poor devil.
Yes, well, I think we ought to go back to the ship and try and find Susan. She should have caught up with us by now. Come along.
Look at that fantastic building! (the pyramid)
Good! Now perhaps we might learn who it is that uses these strange ships. Anyway, lets get back to the ship and find Susan. Later, perhaps, a little visiting, I think.
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Susan has already made it to the pyramid, and the frogman is waiting around the corner with a raised knife. Meanwhile, at the Tardis...

Dialogue.Line: She isn't inside anywhere.
Oh, wretched child. Now where's she got to, I wonder?
Ian, there are your boots. And there are Susan's footprints in the sand here.
Yes, sand here and glass on the beach. I'm beginning to think that sea of acid is a defence barrier.
Except against glass submarines, eh, Doctor?
What you mean is that all visitors are unwelcome.
Yes, it would seem so.
We must find Susan. She may have gone to have a look at that building.
Yes, yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The slab of wall behind the would-be assassin suddenly opens and he falls inside the building just before Susan rounds the corner.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, it's enormous!
Look at the joins in the blocks, Ian.
Yes, no mortar. Must have been built with tremendous accuracy.
Yes, the Egyptians did the same thing. So did the Indians of Central and Southern America.
A precise distribution of weight, that's the key, isn't it?
Yes. Marvellous, isn't it?
Yes, now before you two get carried away, I think we'd better go and find Susan, hmm?
Yes, you're quite right.
Well, for a start, let's make a circuit of this place.
Excellent. Now I suggest we go different ways and meet back at the furthermost point, which is probably round the corner there somewhere. Off you go, off you go now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Susan leans against the wall, it opens under her weight and she screams as she falls in.

Dialogue.Line: Did you hear that?
Yes, it was Susan. Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor also gets pulled inside just before Barbara and Ian arrive.

Dialogue.Line: I could have sworn I heard her.
We certainly heard something. Can't be sure it was Susan, of course.
Well, I am sure.
Yes, but where's the Doctor? Even if he'd been travelling at half speed, he should have reached that far corner by now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Inside the building, Susan is walking slowly down a corridor towards where the frogman is hiding, when a person in a robe passes behind her. She turns, they ignore her, and she continues backwards until the frogman grabs her. She screams, he lets go and falls to the floor with his own knife in his back. The robed figure returns.

Dialogue.Line: Well, Ian, there's only one thing to do. That's another circuit of the walls.
I've just been all around and I couldn't find a door anywhere.
Well, I suppose there's every chance she didn't come this way. She's probably back at the ship waiting for us. I said, she's probably back at the ship waiting for us. Ian? Ian? Ian!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Finally, she leans against the wall too and gets taken inside where we can see a robed figure.
Ian has found the dead frogman. Elsewhere, Barbara and the Doctor have found Susan.

Dialogue.Line: Dreadful. The wall just seemed to swallow me up, and then this man grabbed me and the next thing I knew, he fell dead in front of me.
Man?
Yes, yes. From what Susan has described, he was wearing a suit similar to the one we found on the beach.
Are these the ones that live here?
No, no. The man wearing the monk's habit lives in this building.
So the men from the glass submarines are intruders, like us.
Yes, with one difference, which is puzzling but revealing. They died, and we're only prisoners.
Well maybe we're to be killed, too.
I shouldn't worry too much about that. That young schoolmaster friend of yours is very resourceful. Whilst he's free, our chance of rescue is still good.
Well, that's just it, Doctor. He isn't free. He was captured before I was.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian comes to the rescue of a 'monk' being attacked by another frogman. The frogman falls through another movable wall panel and down a long way into water, or rather, acid.

Dialogue.Line: Why do you protect me?
Are you a prisoner here?
In a way. I can never leave here. In a way, this is my home.
Where are my friends?
Safe. I saw your machine materialise. Until I knew otherwise I had to treat you as potential enemies. The Voord were trying to penetrate the walls.
The Voord?
The man you just saved me from was a Voord. It's many years since their last assault, but now they've returned and if they continue to come they're bound to succeed eventually.
I should have thought this place was impregnable. How many of you defend it?
How many? I am alone. Oh, please, let us release your companions and then I'll try to explain.
Good idea.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Their departure is watched by another frogman.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, yes. I want to know more about this planet. Your technology, you say, reached its peak over two thousand years ago?

Yes, and all our knowledge culminated in the manufacture of this. At the time, it was called the Conscience of Marinus. Marinus, that is the name of our planet. At first, this machine was simply a judge and jury that was never wrong, and unfair. And then we added to it, improved on it, made it more and more sophisticated so that finally it became possible to radiate its power and influence the minds of men throughout the planet. They no longer had to decide what was wrong or right. The machine decided for them.
I see. And in that case it was possible to eliminate evil from the minds of men for all time.

That is exactly what happened. Marinus was unique in the universe. Robbery, fear, hate, violence were unknown among us. Yes, yes, for seven centuries we prospered, and then a man named Yartek found a means of overcoming the power of the machine. He and his followers, the Voords, were able to rob, exploit, kill, cheat. Our people could not resist because violence is alien to them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Voord is eavesdropping on all this.

Dialogue.Line: But surely by this time this machine had become a great danger to you? If it had fallen into the hands of the Voords, they could have controlled Marinus. Why didn't you destroy it?
We always hoped to find a way of modifying it and making it again irresistible. So instead of destroying it, we removed the five key microcircuits.
What did you do with them?

One of them, I kept. There it is. (points up) The other four were taken and put in places of safety all over Marinus. Only I know where they are, and now the time has come when they must be recovered.
Well why don't you simply make new keys?

The keys are very simple, but the microcircuits inside are very complicated. A permutation of numbers and signals that would take a thousand years to unravel. And besides, since the keys were hidden, I have worked on this machine and modified it, so that when they're replaced
When they're replaced it would mean that your machine is irresistible and you can overcome and control the Voords again.
Yes.
Surely there must be someone you can send for these keys?

Through the years all my friends, all my followers, have gone. They have never returned. Last year I sent my daughter. She has not come back. All I have now to comfort me is the distant echo of her voice, the imagined sound of her footsteps. But now your coming's brought new hope. Oh yes, yes, you must find the keys for me.
Ian, wait a minute. The Doctor's miles behind. I don't know about you, but I felt terrible leaving that old man. We seem to be his last hope.
Yes, I wish there had been something we could have done for him.
Oh, come on, Grandfather.
I'm coming, child. Don't rush, I'm coming. Well, don't just stand there, come along, come along. Keeping me waiting.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He tries to put the key in the Tardis lock, but something is forming a barrier a couple of inches away from it.

Dialogue.Line: What?
What is it?
Well, it's some sort of invisible barrier. What do you make of it, Doctor?
I don't know. I don't know. There's no substance here. Have a look round the side, child. Go along.
It's like an invisible wall.
Is it a circular barrier?
Goes all the way round. Can't see a cause to it.

No, of course, there wouldn't be. The molecules would be at their weakest. Ha! It's fascinating, Chesterton. Yes, I've got it, I've got it. You know, I think a force barrier has been put up around the ship.
I am sorry you forced me to keep you from your ship, but your refusal to help me left me no alternative.
Arbitan, where are you?

That is not important. If you help me find the keys of Marinus, I will let you have access to your machine when you have delivered all the keys to me. If not, you will stay on the island without food or water. The choice is yours.
Choice? What choice?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They are looking at a map.

Dialogue.Line: Well, at least we know the rough location of the keys. Now all we have to do is get them.
As soon as you have started your voyage, I will release the forcefield. Your ship will be available to you when you return.
If we return.
I know we have no choice, but this whole affair is outrageous. Blackmail, pure and simply blackmail.
Oh, Doctor, don't lets go through all that again. Let's just get on with the job.
Perhaps you will bring me news of my daughter. I miss her. Yes, I miss her.
And another thing. If you think I'm going to travel across that acid sea in one of these primitive submersibles, you're very much mistaken.
I wouldn't think of asking you to travel in such an absurd way. No, I'm going to give you a device which will enable you to move from place to place.
Oh, really.
The principle is much the same as that of your ship. Place that around your wrist, please. You told me about, except this will enable you to cross space, not time.
What, this little thing?
Oh don't be ridiculous, my boy. This is a perfectly acceptable method of travel. Very compact and very neat, sir, if I may say. Yes.
They're all programmed to the same destination. You have only to twist the dial once.
Like this?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara vanishes.

Dialogue.Line: Barbara!
What! What have you done to Barbara?

You must not waste time. You must follow, quickly. One final word. If when you return, you find the Voord have taken this building, do not let them get the keys. You understand? Destroy them! Now, now, twist the dials.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian, Susan and the Doctor vanish.

Dialogue.Line: For the sake of all my people, I hope you succeed.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Voord sneaks up behind Arbitan and stabs him in the back.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, I can't imagine why Barbara left of her own free will.
No, surely she'd wait for us.
Of course she would.
It seems there's only one conclusion. What ever it is that's behind that door must have taken her by force.
Let's get inside.
No, no, no, no. Don't let us be precipitous.
Doctor, there's blood on this strap. That means she's hurt, maybe badly. We can't argue now. Let's get inside.
Very well, but I say I'm sure it's a mistake.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They force the doors apart and are met by a bright flashing light, an alarm and a lot of statues. Then the flashing stops and they get a good look at the comfortable furniture, urns of plants, and...

Dialogue.Line: I don't believe it.
Ian! Susan! I'm glad you're here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara is dressed Roman style, reclining on a couch and being waited on by two women.

Dialogue.Line: Barbara! You're all right!
Of course I'm all right. In fact I'm better than all right.
We saw your travel dial. There was blood on it.
I know. That was silly. I turned the dial and I seemed to be falling through space. I got frightened and tried to tear it off my wrist. It just scratched me, see.
Well, I must say, quite a nice little place you've got here.
You haven't seen anything yet. Will you get some food for my friends?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The two women bow and leave.

Dialogue.Line: You may be seated.
Your royal highness is most gracious. Perhaps if your majesty will stop hogging the grapes we can all have some.
Help yourself.
Thanks.
This is great.
Well, what do you think about all this, Doctor?
Oh, sensuous and decadent, but rather pleasant. I say, is that a pomegranate?
Yes, here you are.
Extraordinary.
Well, whatever we expected, it certainly wasn't anything like this.
Oh, those silks. They're gorgeous. I'd love a dress made from one of these.
Well, that's what they're here for. They asked me to choose the materials I wanted for my robe.
It's all most remarkable.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A gong sounds and four young women enter with trays of food.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, it's magnificent.
It certainly is.
Hey, I'm starving.
What's the matter? Don't you like it?
No, I've just realised nobody's shown me the menu.
They've got everything here.
Truffles. I do believe they're truffles. Well, well.
Go on, Ian. Have one.
No. You see, I don't know the price yet.
But we're guests here.
You've met the host, have you?
Yes, I have, and his manners are perfect.
So is his kitchen. Delicious.
Hey, we've got a visitor.
This is where we pay the bill.
Oh, relax, Ian.
No, no, don't get up. I apologise for intruding, but I wondered if there was anything you wanted?
There is one thing you could do. Tell us about this place, about your people. Who do we have to thank for all this?
You are in the city of Morphoton. Our people are perhaps the most contented in the universe. Nothing they desire is denied them.
Could I have a dress made
Susan.
No, please, please, let her go on.
Well, I'd love a dress made from this silk here.
Susan, I will not have you take advantage
She takes no advantage. Truly. Our one wish is to fulfil your every need. She shall have the dress.
Thank you. Thank you.
And you? Have you no wish, no great desire?
Well, er, yes, perhaps, but I'm afraid it's not quite as easy as giving Susan a dress out of that.
What is it, Grandfather?
Well, perhaps, if I had to choose, a well equipped laboratory with every conceivable instrument. Yes. Yes.
It will be arranged.
It will? You mean he can have it?

Perhaps in the morning when you see the laboratory, you will find our way of life easier to understand, to believe. Now, as it is late, I suggest you sleep. In the morning, when you wake, you will learn everything about Morphoton.
Hmm. Well, we shall look forward to that.
Yes, and even if you're not serious about the laboratory, we're very grateful
But I am serious. Goodnight.
Goodnight.
Charming young man. Yes, charming. I think a study of this culture is going to prove very, very fascinating. Oh, dear me. I'm tired, you know.
I think the excitement's been too much for Susan, too. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara lies the already-sleeping Susan on a couch.

Dialogue.Line: Well, you don't look very happy.
Me? No, no, no, not at all. Well, I think it's all marvellous.
You're not very convincing. I don't know what you want.
Perhaps it's my materialistic side. How rich and powerful do you have to be to give things away free?
Oh, now don't spoil it all for me.
I didn't mean to do that.
You can't apply Earth standards. You just can't.
No. Certainly very different here. You notice that man's eyes?
What about them?
He didn't blink once. Am I being ridiculous?
Yes. They're just kind, hospitable people.
Yes.
Try to get some sleep. You'll feel differently in the morning.
I suppose it could be worse.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Once they have all laid down and closed their eyes, the eyes on a carving in the wall light up. A woman enters through a secret door and places a device on each of their foreheads, then leaves. But Barbara's head rolls to the side, the device falls off and she sits up. Lights flash and there is a discordant sound. Barbara clutches her head in pain, then passes out.
Next morning, Susan, Ian and the Doctor are having breakfast.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, good morning. Thank you very much.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But the serving girl does not reply.

Dialogue.Line: Most refreshing.
Yes.
Look at these exquisite glasses, Chesterton.
Can I have some more orange juice, please?
Why not? Help yourself, there's plenty more.
Now, now, child. Don't take it all. We must leave some for Barbara when she wakes up.
Yes, Barbara. She really is having a deep sleep, isn't she?
What's the matter, hmm?
Oh, this, oh, I don't know. Just a sort of mild irritation on the forehead. It's nothing at all.
No, there's nothing there. I only mentioned it because I have rather a sore spot here myself.
Oh, look! Look, Grandfather, it's my dress. Thank you. Thank you. It's beautiful, look.
Yes, it really is very elegant, Susan.
Can I show Barbara? Can I wake her up?
Why not. She can't sleep all the morning.
Barbara. Barbara. Wake up. Wake up.
What's happened?
What's the matter?
Well, look. Look around you. Can't you see?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: From Barbara's viewpoint, the room is dusty and dirty, not elegant and luxurious any more.

Dialogue.Line: I don't think she's properly awake. Susan, get me a glass of that fruit juice, will you?
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But instead of a glass goblet, he offers her a china mug.

Dialogue.Line: Here, drink this.
No, it's filthy!
Now you've broken it.
Barbara, what's got into you?
Why can't you see?
This is going to test our host's patience, you know. It's one of a set.
It's just a dirty old mug. And the room, why have they changed it?
It's the same, Barbara.
No it isn't. It isn't. And this terrible dress. And the furniture.
What's happened to her?
Why can't you see it?
Barbara, Barbara.
It's all changed!
Come on, now, get a hold of yourself.
Don't be frightened, Barbara.
Ian, try to see. Please. Try to see the truth.
Don't be afraid. Look. They brought me my dress.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara sees a tatty sack-cloth thing.

Dialogue.Line: It's dirty. Dirty rags.
Barbara, these people are very kind to us. They've given us everything.
They've given you nothing. I don't know what they've done to you, or why it hasn't worked on me, but I must find a way to show you. I must, before it's too late.
Ah, here comes Altos. Now perhaps he can convince you.
He knows it's failed on me.
What's the matter? Aren't you feeling well? Let me take you to our physicians.
No. No.
Please, I only want to help you.
No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara runs out of the room.

Dialogue.Line: Barbara!
Please, don't concern yourself. She's overwrought. I'll deal with it. You stay here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara manages to hide from Altos in another room, but when she tries the door again, she can't get back out.
On a table, in a pair of glass cases, are things that look like brains with eyes on stalks sticking out of the top on them.

Dialogue.Line: One of the women has resisted the power of the mesmerant. She has escaped into the city.
Who placed the discs?
The girl Sabetha.

She has failed us and must be punished. Return now to the other three. Reassure them about their friend. Take them to their laboratory. In four hours we will give them the final exposure to the mesmerant. They will be completely subjugated.
And what of the one that has escaped?
She has seen the truth, and is beyond our control. Find her and destroy her.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara hides again when she hears someone coming through the door. Then she sees who it is.

Dialogue.Line: You're the girl who put the discs on our foreheads.
I made a mistake. I am to be punished.
Tell me all you can about this place.
I am to be punished.
Listen to me. I believe you're under some deep form of deep hypnosis.
I am to be punished.
Oh, what's the use?
The physician says she was in a highly nervous condition. She is now under deep sedation. She will soon recover.
Well, that's a relief. Perhaps we can visit her later?
Yes, of course.
Yes, yes, well, naturally we're all glad that she's going to be all right, so if there's nothing more we can do for her, I suggest we get a look at the laboratory, hmm?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Altos opens the door and they go in.
It's really an empty room, but Ian and Doctor are under the influence of Morpho, remember.

Dialogue.Line: I've never seen anything like it!
I think I shall find considerable scope here.
Doctor, isn't that a cyclotron?
What? Oh, yes, yes, yes, yes. A simple toy. I'm sure that will amuse you. Ah, now this might be helpful.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He picks up a battered mug.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, if I can have instruments like these, I might be able to overcome the fault in the time mechanism aboard the ship.
They really can do it, eh? They can give you anything you ask for.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sabetha is stroking a medallion.

Dialogue.Line: Where did you get this?
It's mine.
I don't want to take it away from you. I just want to know where you got it.
They gave it to me. My masters. It was the thing I desired most. It's mine.
But why? Why did you want it?
It's mine.
Listen to me. Does the name Arbitan mean anything to you? Arbitan?
Arbitan?
Oh, please, please try to remember.
Arbitan. He sent me here. I was. I can't remember.
Is Arbitan your father?

Open the panel. They're sleeping soundly. Altos is placing the Somnar discs. Already I sense their will beginning to weaken, memories fading. When they wake, all resistance will have ended. They will remember no more.
What are your orders for them when they have recovered?

The two men will join the working parties. We can use the younger one's strength with the haulage gangs. The old man is weaker, but intelligent. Isolate him and put him to work on the scheme for increasing my powers. As for the child, she must be trained rapidly. She will take the place of Sabetha, the one that failed us.
And what of the one that has escaped?
That is your responsibility. As soon as it is light, a thorough search must be made. If you fail, you will be killed. She must be found.
Concentrate, Sabitha, please. Look, we're almost finished.
I can't remember any more. I feel so sleepy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara hears footsteps, and hides. Altos enters and goes to Sabetha.

Dialogue.Line: You are to come with me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He turns and sees Barbara. They struggle. Sabetha hits him over the head with a pot.

Dialogue.Line: Sabetha, I must find the others and try and convince them. If I succeed, I'll come back for you.
Ian! Oh, thank heaven I've found you. Oh, I thought they must have got to you. I thought. Ian?
You must be the one who escaped. The one they told me about.
Ian!
I must take you to them.
So, she has been caught. You have done well and proved yourself worthy.
It's disgusting. Ian, can't you see how you're being used?

We are the masters of this place. Our brains out-grew our bodies. It is our intelligence that has created this whole city, but we need the help of the human body to feed us and to carry out our orders.
You use your people to act as machines for you.
Much more than machines. The human body is the most flexible instrument in the world. No single mechanical device could reproduce its mobility and dexterity.
So I'm to become one of your slaves?
No. You have seen the truth of our city. It is beyond our power to erase this from your memory. You must be destroyed. Kill her. Kill her.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian puts his hands around Barbara's throat.

Dialogue.Line: Ian.
Kill her. Kill her. Kill her.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara breaks free and starts smashing the place up.

Dialogue.Line: Kill her! Kill her! Argh!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She gets to the bell jars with the brains, and the things inside them die.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, oh, where are we? Barbara! Barbara.
It's all right, Ian. It's all right now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara is out of the tatty dress and in her jumper and slacks again.

Dialogue.Line: They're burning the city!
Yes. I don't blame them. Trouble is, they'll be up here soon.
Seeking their revenge, are they? Poor creatures.
Ian thinks we should get out of here as soon as possible.
Yes, I do.
Where's Susan?
We're all meeting here. She's bringing Sabetha and that young man Altos. I questioned him and there's no doubt about it. He's one of Arbitan's couriers.
They're coming with us?
Yes. He's going with you, certainly. By the way, I found these travel dials. Those repellant brain things didn't appreciate their significance, fortunately.
Doctor, what did you mean, Altos is going with you?
I will explain it all in good time. Ah, here are the others.
Good. Let's go, then.
No, wait. Now, we have one key and there are three more to find.
Yes. Sabetha wanted to continue the search with us.
I wish to join you, too.
Good idea.
I was sent by Arbitan. I and a friend called Eprin. Our plan was as follows. He would go ahead in search of key four, and I would come here for the first.
Arbitan hadn't heard from either of you. Or anyone else, for that matter.
Well, we must presume something has happened to your friend Eprin.
It may just be that he couldn't reach the key. It lies somewhere in the city of Millenius.
Ah, yes, the place you mentioned, yes. The highly civilised society. Now then, I've decided to adopt his plan.
What? You mean go two jumps ahead and try and find the fourth key?
Yes, precisely. I shall try and find out what's happened to your friend Eprin. If he's alive, make contact, then we can all meet again.
Do you know how to adjust the dial, Grandfather?
Yes, Altos has shown me how to adjust mine.
Yours? Well, aren't I coming?
No. I think it better if you travel with the main party, child.
But I want to go with you!

Yes, yes, I know, Susan, but don't you see it's better if we split our forces. You see, it's a very dangerous situation and the sooner we get on with it, the better. For my part, I know you'll be well looked after. And as for me, well, I'm going to a well-ordered society and I think it's the best and speediest way, really.
All right. Won't be for long though, will it?
No.
I was wondering if we should fix a time to meet.
Say five days.
Yes, that's not a bad idea. But you'd better give us another two just in case of possible delays.
I hope everything won't be as bad as this place.
No, I hope not. Put these on, please.
Well, goodbye Doctor, and take care of yourself.
Oh, of course I will. And you see that you take good care of Susan.
Yes, we will.
Well, I'm ready.
So am I. I wish you well, Doctor.
Thank you, my dear. Now off you go.
Goodbye, Grandfather.
Goodbye, my child.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Susan disappears.

Dialogue.Line: Susan! She should have waited for us.
Now, quickly. You must go and follow her.
Susan.
Oh, go back!
What is it?
We can't stay here. It's stopped.
What did you see?
What's the matter?
Susan, answer me.
Didn't you hear it?
There could be animals in this jungle around us.
No, no, it wasn't anything like that.
Take it easy, Susan, and try and tell us what it was you heard.
Well, well, it was horrible.
She'll tell us in time. Look, Susan, whatever it was, it's gone now.
I did hear it, you know.
Yes.
This is a dead place.
Yes, it's very quiet, isn't it.
That isn't quite what I meant.
The key must be on the other side of this wall.
Yes. Some sort of an archway. Look at these creepers.
Some of them are almost as thick as small trees.
And was Grandfather all right?
Yes.
I didn't want to stay until the last possible moment. I don't like to say goodbye.
No, I know.
I suppose we could cut them down.
Not unless we have to. Take us the best part of a day to hack that little lot down. The best thing we can do is take a walk round these walls.
Oh yes, that would be wise. Then we might find another entrance.
I'll go with you.
Ian, Susan and I will stay here.
All right. We won't be long, anyway.
We'll look around for some branches and things in case we have to force our way though that arch.
That's a good idea, but don't do anything until we get back, hey?
All right.
Come on, let's try this way.
I do wish Ian wouldn't treat us like Dresden china.
I think it's nice the way he looks after us all the time.
Yes, I know, but just once in a while
You rebel.
Yes. How are you feeling now?
Oh, I'm all right, thank you.
Susan, what did happen?
Well, it was a sound. A noise like tapping, and whirring, all mixed up with a screeching. I've heard it before.
Where?
Well that's just it. I can't remember. I just recognise it as being something evil.
You know, I've never seen vegetation as dense as this before. It'll overrun the building in time.
Do you think the key's inside, Barbara?
Oh yes, it must be. It's a funny old place, isn't it? You know, in a few years these walls will be so weak you could push your way through.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meanwhile, a climbing plant is moving on its own toward where Susan is lying on the ground, relaxing.

Dialogue.Line: You know, Susan, looking at this archway, I'm not at all sure. It isn't half as dense as it looks. I'm sure we could get through.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The plant has grabbed Susan's ankle. She screams.

Dialogue.Line: Barbara! Barbara!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara gets the plant off Susan and thumps it with a rock.

Dialogue.Line: It was alive! A snake crawling all over me!
No, no. It must have fallen on you from the trees.
It didn't, it didn't. It's alive.
Now stop it, Susan. Stop it.
It was trying to twine all round me.
It was just your imagination.
I'm sorry.
It couldn't move by itself. You know it couldn't.
No.
Come on over here and help me at the archway. You know, you'll frighten me if you go on like this.
Oh look, you can move some of these back quite easily.
Yes, I thought so.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She goes through the archway.

Dialogue.Line: What is it?
I'm not sure. It's so dark in here. There's a statue at the end of the tunnel. An idol or something.
Be careful, Barbara. Barbara? Barbara? Are you all right?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara has reached the idol in its niche. It has an animal face, sunburst hair and open arms.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, please don't go any further!
It's all right, I can see it now. It's a big grotesque statue.
Oh, there's no other way in, Susan.
Oh, Ian, thank goodness you're here.
What? Where's Barbara?
She's gone down here.
Barbara! What are you doing? I told you to wait until we got back.
I thought there was a way through. Ian, look! The key, the microcircuit, I've found it!
Hang on, I'm coming.
No, no, it's all right, I can reach it.
What's happening?
Barbara's found the micro-key.
Wonderful.
Can you manage?
Yes, yes, I think I've got it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She climbs up the statue and triggers some mechanism. The statue's arms close around her legs.

Dialogue.Line: Ian! Help me! Help me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The men dash in through the archway but the statue pivots round and when they get there it is just a blank wall.

Dialogue.Line: You see what happened?
Yes. Is there no break in the wall? Perhaps there's a hidden spring.
Well if there is, I can't find it.
Well we must get inside.
Yes, but how? Oh, let's get out in the open. I can't think in here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Altos finds the micro-key on the floor.

Dialogue.Line: Barbara's disappeared. That idol thing was on some sort of a pivot.
At least she found the micro-key.
Oh, I don't care about that now. The only thing that matters is getting Barbara out of there.
Yes, I agree. Here, Sabetha, you'd better take this. Keep it with the other, and keep it safe.
Thank you. Look, I don't want to raise false hopes, but perhaps things aren't as bad as they seem.
What do you mean?
Well, Barbara was wearing her travel dial, wasn't she?
Yes. None of us have taken them off.
Then as long as she wasn't injured when she was trapped, she can escape whenever she wants.
It's a possibility.
Well, I'm sure she would have thought of that.
Yes, of course. She may not have taken advantage of it yet. Anything might have happened to her.
But if she was in danger, she'd have to use her travel dial.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They hear the mechanism.

Dialogue.Line: It's turning again. Now the arms are open.
That means it either must have released her or she's escaped.
She may have been injured, or even
But if she used her travel dial, and gone on to the next destination, we don't know what danger she may be in there.
No. Well, we must cover all possibilities to the best of our abilities. You'd better go on ahead with Susan and Altos.
Yes, that's wise. I think that is the wisest course.
Ian, what are you going to do?
I'm going back in there. If that idol works once as a trap, there's no reason why it shouldn't work again. Once inside, well, if there's no sign of Barbara, I'll follow you as quickly as I can.
Well, if that's settled, there's no point in delaying. You ready, Sabetha? Susan?
Can't I come with you, Ian?
No, Susan. Better not.
We'll wait for you, Ian.
And I'll be your guardian, Susan.
Look after her, Altos.
Take care, my friend.
Goodbye, Ian.
Good luck.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Altos and Susan vanish. Sabetha has dropped the micro-key.

Dialogue.Line: Here, you'd better put this on your chain with the other one. We don't want you losing it somewhere in outer space.
That would be terrible. There. I think that's safe enough. This isn't it.
What?
It's just an imitation. Look, Ian. This edge is a fraction shorter.
Are you absolutely sure? I mean, isn't it possible there was some genuine variation in the original micro-keys?
No, they all look absolutely identical, so this one must be an imitation.
We're no further on than when we arrived here.
Do you want me to stay with you?
No. You go on ahead with the others. They'll be worried already. Tell them what happened, and tell them I'll follow as soon as I find the real micro-key.
Please be careful.
I will. Off you go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He goes to the statue, it holds him and turns around.
There are plenty of statues and plants here. Ian steps on a loose paver and an axeman starts working.

Dialogue.Line: Ian, behind you!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian gets out of the way of the axe.

Dialogue.Line: You're not hurt?
No, just a bit shaken. Barbara, if you hadn't shouted
Never mind about that now. Ian, I've been so frightened. If you hadn't turned up in another half an hour I was going to turn the travel dial.
I'm glad you didn't. That micro-key you found, it was a fake.
What?
Yes. The real one must be in here somewhere.
And I warn you it's not going to be easy to find.
No?
This whole place is one big booby-trap. It's full of things like that statue. I'd only been here a minute when part of the wall crashed down just where I'd been standing.
We'll take it very slowly. That doorway looks a good place to start. Any idea where it leads to?
No. Into the building, I suppose.
Well, that's a likely place to hide a key. Come on.
These vines are everywhere. They seem to be crawling all over the building.
Not only the vines. It's all vegetation. Look at that wall.
It seems to be trying to get in.
Let's get the micro-key and get out of here. It looks as if we're going to have to break this door down. It's pretty solid. I shall need something to. I wish I could.
I saw some iron bars in an alcove down there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An old man apparently opens the door.

Dialogue.Line: Ian. Ian!
I'll be right with you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara goes inside and a net drops on her from the ceiling. She sees the ceiling has knives sticking out of it, and it is descending towards her. She screams.
Ian tugs at an iron bar, but it has a chain attached to it and he gets trapped behind an iron grating.

Dialogue.Line: Ian! Ian!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He tries to use another bar to prise the grating open.

Dialogue.Line: Help me, Ian. Help me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The old man reverses the mechanism.

Dialogue.Line: Why have you come in search of the keys?
Help me.
Who are you? What interest have you in the keys?
Look, I can't talk to you like this. Let me go.
Are you a Voord? You do not resemble their race and yet
Arbitan sent us.
That is a lie.
No, it's true. He was alone on the island. He couldn't send anyone else.
How can you prove it?
I don't know. Look, where's Ian? What have you done to him?
How can you prove that Arbitan sent you.
Oh, the travel dial on my wrist.
I will examine this, and if it is set correctly with the proper journey programme I shall know that you speak the truth. Only Arbitan could set your complete journey.
What have you done with Ian?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But the man leaves her. Ian is still trying to get through his bars, and succeeds. The man meanwhile has got caught by a vine and is being throttled.

Dialogue.Line: Help me! Help me!
Barbara. Are you all right?
Yes. In there.
What?
In here.
Help me!
Help! Help me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian uses a bar or sword to cut him free.

Dialogue.Line: It's coming again. The jungle is coming. When the whispering starts, it's death, I tell you. Death!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Later, the old man is in his bed.

Dialogue.Line: He's coming round, Ian. Ian, I think he's dying.
You must not stay here.
Listen to me. Where is the micro-key? We're looking for it. Do you understand? Arbitan sent us.
Has Arbitan sent someone at last?
Yes.
The idol. I put a false key on its head.
Yes, I found it.
I know. A system of mirrors. When the false key was taken I put my traps in motion. Only those warned by Arbitan could avoid them.
He's getting weaker, Ian. I wish there was something I could do. I feel so helpless.
I haven't long to live, have I?
You must trust us. Tell us, where is the micro-key?
Closer. D E 3 O 2.
What do you mean? I don't understand.
Quickly, the darkness! The whispering will start.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He dies.

Dialogue.Line: He pointed to this door. What did the numbers and the letters mean?
I don't know. Could be the combination to a safe. Let's go and see.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Furniture, pot plants.

Dialogue.Line: Ian, you were right. It is a safe.
And a combination one, at that.
D E 3 O 2.
Hello. It's only got the letters on. Perhaps the figures were the numbers of turns?
Yes, try it.
D E 1 2 3 O 1 2. It doesn't work. Are you sure we got it right?
Yes, certain.
Try again. D E 1 2 3 O 1 2. No, no, it doesn't work. Well, I suppose he could have hidden the combination somewhere.
Yes, I suppose so. There's also a possibility that he didn't mean the safe at all. Judging by the traps and decoys around here, I should think the obvious hiding place is the least likely.
We must go over this room inch by inch. Eliminating everything but the safe. Then if we haven't found it, it must be in here.
I'll start over here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Much later.

Dialogue.Line: Ian, I've been trying to think back. What did he mean, darkness, the whispering will begin. Whispering? I wonder if that's what Susan heard?
I don't know. I think he was rambling, he didn't mean anything. I'm hoping to find a lead in here. It's a diary of his experiments.
What was he working on?
Biology seems to have been his field as far as I can make out.
Well, judging by the specimens in here, I'd say he was very successful.

Yes. Last couple of entries are a bit strange. All about the balance of nature and increased destructive forces. Listen to this. Nature has a fixed tempo of destruction. Water dripping on a stone may take a thousand years to produce any sign of wear.
Well, that's not very original.
It is if you could speed up everything. The wear on the stone could happen in one day.
But that's ridiculous.
Is it? He didn't seem to think so. He ends up by saying, the growth accelerator has changed nature's tempo of destruction entirely.
Yes, well that may all be very fascinating, but we are supposed to be looking for the combination to that safe.
All right. All right.
You know, it's quite dark outside. Have you looked through this one?
No.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The noises start.

Dialogue.Line: What's that?
I don't know. It sounds like whispering. He said it would begin when darkness came. That must be what Susan heard.
Well, what's causing it?
Shush. Listen. It's like someone trying to get in.
You said that when we were outside, about the jungle.
But it couldn't, Ian, it couldn't.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tendrils are pushing through the walls.

Dialogue.Line: Look! Oh, Barbara, don't you see? It's what he meant. Tempo of destruction. It would normally take fifty or a hundred years for a jungle to overrun this place. Now the whole process has been accelerated.
You mean the jungle is attacking us?
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara's ankles get grabbed by a vine, and while he is freeing her, Ian spots the label on a broken glass jar - NH4NO3.

Dialogue.Line: Look, Barbara. It's a chemical formula! DE3O2. The micro-key's in one of these jars. Come on! Quickly, find it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She does.

Dialogue.Line: Ian, the key!
Barbara, you've found it! Let's get out of here, quickly. Turn the travel dial, now! Now!

Episodes.Episode: Episode Four - The Snows of Terror

Dialogue.Line: It's no good, Ian. I'm too tired. Sleep.
No!
I must sleep.
No. No, Barbara. We'll freeze to death.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They both pass out. Barbara wakes briefly to see someone dressed in furs standing over her. He takes the micro-key from her hand.
The wind is howling outside, but there's a fire in the grate. The man wakes Barbara again.

Dialogue.Line: Don't be afraid. You're safe now.
Oh, how did I? Ian? Where's Ian?
Your friend is here. He still sleeps. Your hand is slightly frostbitten. Put it in mine. We must help your friend like this too. Rub the hand slowly, like this. Yes? Understand? Are you afraid of me?
No.
Last year I broke the back of a wolf with my bare hands. I'm Vasar. Most men fear me, so I have few visitors. There, see? The blood is beginning to return.
Thank you.
I'll get a warm drink for both of you.
Ian, wake up. How are you feeling?
Oh, my hands.
Yes, they're swollen with frostbite. No, no, no, you mustn't put them near the fire. You have to bring back the circulation slowly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara strokes his hand.

Dialogue.Line: Where are we?
I don't know. I don't even know how we got here.
Ah, you're awake. Good. Here, drink this.
Oh, thank you. Mmm. Oh, that's better. Do we have you to thank for saving us on the mountain.
I found you when I was resetting my traps. Had a difficult journey getting you back to the hut.
We would have frozen to death.
The wolves would have eaten you first.
Wolves?
Yes, there are more than ever of them this winter. I've counted a dozen packs, twenty in each. They're hungry. They're even raiding the villages at night.
Are we in a village?
No, the nearest village is three miles away. I stay out here to look after my traps.
Well, we're grateful to you, getting to us before the wolves.
One of you would have died anyway if it hadn't been for the stranger. Couldn't carry you both.
Stranger? What stranger?
A madman. Came in here early last night, raving and ranting. I couldn't talk to him. Gave him some clothes and went with him up the mountain. He was searching for a couple of girls.
Altos!
Where is he now?
In the village, I think. After we got you back here, I think he went out.
Did he say he was coming back?
Yes, but it's getting nearly dark. He won't be able to get over the ledge at night.
We must go and help him.
There's a storm coming up.
You've already done so much for us. I can't ask you to risk coming with me, but will you lend me warm clothing?
Lend you? My furs are my living. I'm a poor man. I wouldn't have much chance of getting them back if you fall down a crevice.
I can't pay you for them. I haven't got any money.
That thing on your wrist looks valuable.
Yes, all right. Now please, hurry.
All right, coat and gloves over there. I'll get you a lantern.
Ian, Susan and Sabetha, do you think you'll find them?
I don't know what to think, Barbara. I'll know more when and if I find Altos.
Here you are. The village lies that way. When you get through the fur forest you'll see the lights.
Well, thank you.
Ian.
I'll be back as soon as I can.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian leaves, and Vasar bolts the door behind him.

Dialogue.Line: Now, we're alone.
Oh, he'll be back. I know he will.
We'll see. Well I'll go and get us some food. We must fatten you up, eh?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian finds Altos lying in the snow. His hands have been tied together.
The wolves are howling.

Dialogue.Line: They sound so close.
You're safe here. That door'll keep anything out. Or in. You clear those things will you, and I'll get rid of these.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara opens a drawer in the table and finds - three travel dials and...

Dialogue.Line: Sabetha's chain.
What are you doing in that drawer?
Where did you get these? One of the girls was wearing this.
You give me those. They're worth money.
How did you get them?
There's a cave on the mountain where I store my traps. I found the two girls hiding there.
So they're alive.
They may be. That was yesterday. I gave them food and flint in return for these, and I left them there.
But why? Why didn't you bring them back?
Oh, don't keep annoying me. These accusations. I can't afford to look after every fool that gets lost on the mountains.
They gave you all those things in the drawer.
Trinkets.
But what about Altos? The young man, who
He forced me to go up the mountain to look for these girls. Instead we found you. And when we'd brought you back here he wanted to go out again.
I don't believe you. You stole those things.
Oh, did I?
They might have given you the wrist bracelets, but the keys and the chain? Sabetha would never have parted with them.
Yes, I thought they were valuable.
What have you done with them? You didn't kill them?
You don't kill anyone in this country. The cold and the wolves do that.
Well, when Ian gets back
What makes you think he will get back? He doesn't know what's in that bag I gave him.
What did you put in it? Tell me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian is trying to get Altos' circulation going.

Dialogue.Line: They're getting closer. We can't stay here. How are your legs?
The feeling's beginning to return. I should be able to walk in a minute or two.
You haven't yet told me who tied you up.
The trapper.
What? But he rescued us.
Only because I forced him to. He's utterly ruthless.
Barbara's back there with him. Alone!
We must get back there as quickly as we can. Come on, help me up.
All right. Can you stand?
Yes.
Just a minute, look at this. Raw meat. What on earth would Vasar want to give me that for?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Wolves howl.

Dialogue.Line: There's your answer. Those beasts could scent meat a couple of miles away. Draw them like a magnet. Vasar's making certain you wouldn't get back.
Well he's got a surprise coming, hasn't he.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian throws the bag away.

Dialogue.Line: Come on.
There's nowhere you can run.
Keep away.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She picks up the poker.

Dialogue.Line: Put that down.
Don't you dare come near me.
All right, I'm in no hurry. There's no one coming to help you. I can wait.
They're catching up.
Look!
About a quarter of a mile, I make it. I think we've got a chance, but we'll have to run, Altos.
All right, I'll try. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara has had to defend her honour with the poker, and has hurt Vasar.

Dialogue.Line: All right, I'll wait no longer.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He chases her around the table, she stumbles and screams, then there's a hammering at the door. Vasar is immobile with surprise, so Barbara runs to the door.

Dialogue.Line: Barbara, open the door!
Come back.
Open the door!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara bites Vasar's hand and pulls back the bolts.

Dialogue.Line: Open the door! Open the door!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian and Altos enter.

Dialogue.Line: Are you all right?
Yes, the girls are all right. They're in a cave in the mountain.
I meant them no harm, I swear it. I gave them food and flint to light a fire.
You treacherous
No, Altos. We want him unharmed. He's going to show us where the cave is.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Susan is failing to keep the fire going.

Dialogue.Line: I'm sorry, Sabetha.
It doesn't matter. There is hardly any wood left.
Look, there's no point in us waiting here. We must go out there and take a chance.
In these clothes? We wouldn't last an hour.
How long do you think we'll last here without any fire?
I suppose you're right.
Come on, then.
That isn't the way we came in. It was the tunnel on the right.
Well I'm sure it was this one.
I could have sworn it. Well, if you're certain.
I thought I was certain. You've made me doubtful now.
Come on, let's try it.
How much further?
It's just beyond the next ridge. When we get there, can I go back?
You're getting no promises out of me. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The girls have come to a dead end.

Dialogue.Line: Now we've got to go back.
I'm sorry, Sabetha.
It's not your fault. Don't worry, we'll just go back the way we came. Come on.
They're not here.
Look, there's been a fire. I told you I helped them.
This ash is still warm. They can't have been gone long.
Is there another way out of these caves?
No, this is the only one.
How far do these tunnels go?
Oh, right through the mountain.
Then they must have gone in deeper. Lead on, Vasar.
No! No! No! We mustn't! There are demons in there. I won't go on.
I am not asking you, I'm telling you. Now, move!
It's no good, Sabetha. We're just going deeper into the mountain.
If we keep going, we must find a way out. Now, come on.
Oh, look. We've got a rope bridge.
Be careful. Is it safe?
I think so.
Don't look down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Susan gets to the other side of the narrow chasm, and Sabetha follows.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, let's move quickly.
I've just realised. This wall isn't rock, it's solid ice.
Oh, please, we mustn't go on. I told you the truth when I said there were demons here. There are men who've seen them.
Well, who knows, you might be a man who's seen them too. You're not going back, anyway. Come on, get on. Go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They come to the rope bridge as Susan and Sabetha come to a room with four knights in armour standing guard around a block of ice. They run back into the arms of their would-be rescuers.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, Barbara!
Hang on, I'm coming over.
Ian.
Thank you. Oh, Susan. Here, put this round you.
I though we'd never get out of there.
Well, you're all right now. What happened?
What was it that frightened you?
Down there. There's somebody down there.
We almost ran into them.
Ian, stop him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: On the other side of the five foot gap, Vasar is unfastening the rope bridge. He throws it down.

Dialogue.Line: Vasar, wait.
No, you wait. Wait there forever. There's no other way out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Vasar leaves.

Dialogue.Line: What a fool I was.
How do we get across?
I don't know. It's too wide to jump.
Well, maybe we could find some planks or logs and lay them across.
Yes, all right. Let's go and look.
Shall I lead the way?
Yes.
Sabetha, keep close behind me. Look out for this slope.
Yes. Mind the slope. All right? Altos, look out! This rock's the only thing supporting this block of ice.
It might have crushed us to death.
Yes, well the only thing to do is keep away from it. Keep down as you go under.
Yes, I agree.
Right down.
Can't we go back?
No, Susan, we must find the key.
Susan, we must search all these tunnels properly. That key's probably hidden somewhere here, inside the mountain.
Not there!
We have no alternative.
Is this what you saw, Susan?
Yes. But they seem so life-like.
These must be the demons that Vasar talked about. Well they're certainly the stuff that make legends.
Look, right in the middle of the ice. It's the key.
Yes. It couldn't be better protected, could it? A solid block of ice.
And four dead warriors to guard it, eh? Each perfectly preserved. They certainly look frightening enough, don't they.
There's a pipe here. It runs right round the block of ice.
Oh, yes, look. It comes out over here. You can see it running underneath the ice.
Ian, over here. It's a sort of valve, or something.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She starts turning it.

Dialogue.Line: Whoa, steady on. Go on turning it. It's getting warmer. (the pipe)
But how could it be? Where could the heat come from?
Must be a volcanic spring buried deep in the bowels of the earth. Like the hot springs in Iceland.
Iceland? Where's that?
In our own country, far away.
It's melting.
Quite quickly.
Well, while we're waiting for it to melt, let's go and see what we can do about that bridge.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian is tying two logs together.

Dialogue.Line: With any luck they'll freeze together. Cold on the hands, isn't it. Well, lets get it over. Careful. We don't want it to break. Right, slide it along that one gently. Right, now careful when it comes off the end. Careful. Oh, it didn't break. Right, let's get some more, pile them round. Where are the girls?
I asked them to go and see how the melting process was coming along.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two of the guards look as if they've fallen over.

Dialogue.Line: The key!
Ian, Altos, it's all right. The ice has melted.
Hey, look at these weapons. Wouldn't like to come across one of these in a battle.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard straightens up.

Dialogue.Line: He's alive! He's alive!
What's the matter? Get out of here! Run! Have you got the key?
Yes!
Then run!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The four guards advance slowly on Ian blocking the exit.
Susan ties part of the old rope bridge around her wrist, then slowly crawls onto Ian's new bridge.

Dialogue.Line: Susan.
It'll never take her weight. It can't have frozen solid yet.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A piece of the wood breaks away but she keeps going. Ian pulls down the rock that is holding up the ice wall to hold up the guards. Susan makes it to the other side and pulls the old rope bridge back into place.

Dialogue.Line: Well done, Susan. Come on, Sabetha. Get ready. You first.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guards get past the fallen rock as the adults cross the rope bridge.

Dialogue.Line: Right, you carry on. I'll catch you up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian unfastens the rope bridge, and a guard falls screaming down into the crevasse.
Vasar is gloating over the travel dials and micro-keys when the travellers burst in.

Dialogue.Line: What? How did you get?
We've come to collect our things, Vasar.
No! No! No! No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Vasar runs out.

Dialogue.Line: Here, Sabetha, put those round your neck. Now, put the travel dial on. We've all got our travel dials on? We'll keep our date with the Doctor.
They're coming, they're coming. The devils from the mountain are coming here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There's a hammering at the door.

Dialogue.Line: I'm afraid you'll have to entertain them alone, Vasar. We have to leave you.
(grabbing Susan) No! You stay, you hear? Stay, or I'll kill her.
Take your hands off her.
I'm going out the back way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He lets go of Susan then falls forward. He's been stabbed in the back by a sword stuck through the door.

Dialogue.Line: He's dead. The dials, quick, the dials.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The three guards burst in and find no one alive.
The alarm has stopped when Ian wakes up with a bad headache, and discovers that the key is gone.

Dialogue.Line: Do you want to tell me where you've hidden it?
Who are you?
My name is Tarron. I'm an interrogator in the Guardian Division. You feel well enough to talk?
Well, my head's pretty sore. What happened here?
I'm waiting for you to tell me.
Me? I don't know much. I just came through that door.
It was unlocked?
It was ajar. I saw the body on the floor, I bent down to have a look, and someone hit me on the head from behind.
You could not have come through that door unless the guard on duty in here let you in.
It was open. I've already told you.
This is a maximum security vault. No one is admitted until they've undergone a complete probity check. There's no record of you ever having completed such a check.
Well of course there isn't. I've never been here before.
However, you did get inside. I must assume that you either tricked the guard there or you were in league with him.
What? What are you talking about? I told you how I got in.
Yes, and I'm recording all your answers. Do you feel well enough? Are you going to tell me the truth?
Yes, well, as far as I can, but
Well, let's be orderly about this. Name?
Ian Chesterton.
You are a visitor to this district?
Yes.
Your work?
I'm a teacher. Science.
Hmm. You know the purpose of the micro-key? No reply. It would make my report complete if you would tell me how you got rid of the micro-key.
I didn't get rid of it. I never had it. I saw it in that glass case before someone hit me on the back of the head.
While you were unconscious, my men searched the room. They searched you and the body of the guard. They didn't find it. Now, what did you do with it?
I didn't do anything with it. I told you all I know.
All right. (into telephone) Open your side. We're coming out.
Where are we going?
To the Guardian building. You will be charged formally.
Charged? With what?
Murder.
Just a minute, what's your name? Tarron?
Yes.
This business is beginning to run away from me. I've told you the truth!
That isn't for me to decide.
But there was another man in here. I've got a lump on the back of my head to prove it.
The dead man could have hit you before he was killed.
I suppose I killed him while I was unconscious.
Well it does suggest you had an accomplice, I agree. So you had better produce him. That's my advice to you, for what it's worth.
I don't have to produce him, Tarron. You do. This is circumstantial evidence. You must prove that I did the actual killing.
That is contrary to our legal system.
What?
I mean that you are already guilty of this crime. The burden of defence is entirely yours. You must prove without any shadow of doubt that you are innocent, otherwise
Otherwise?
You will die. If you will take my advice, you will find someone to speak for you at the tribunal. Do you know any body in the city?
Yes, I do know someone, if I can find him.
Who is he?
Who? He's a doctor.
Permission has been granted for you to attend the court proceedings.
Thank you.
But I'm to tell you there must be no disturbances of any kind. The laws are very rigid. Offenders can be sent for one year to the glass factories in the desert, instantly and without trial.
I understand.
Chief Enquirer Tarron has arranged for you to speak to your friend, but you do understand that you mustn't give him any packets or articles not previously examined by me, yes? Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara goes to sit with Altos, as Sabetha and Susan enter.

Dialogue.Line: Any news?
No, not a sign of him anywhere.
Several people saw him only two days ago.
Was that before or after Ian was arrested.
Well, after, as far as we can work it out.
I haven't been able to find out anything about my friend Eprin either.
Well, we've got permission to see Ian, anyway.
Oh, good. Couldn't we make a dash for it?
No, it's too dangerous.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian and Tarron enter.

Dialogue.Line: How are you?
They're treating me well enough. Have you found the Doctor yet?
No. There isn't a sight or sound of him anywhere.
We must find him, Barbara. We must. The laws in this country are a mockery.
I quite agree with you, my boy.
Doctor!
Grandfather!
How did you get here?
We looked everywhere.
I'm just glad we're back together again.
Yes, so am I, dear child. So am I. However, we have some important work to attend to. Excuse me. Chesterton, you and I must have a talk.
We haven't much time for a talk, Doctor. In a moment I've got to go in there and face an accusation of murder. I need a man to defend me.
I am that man.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The three judges take their places on the bench.

Dialogue.Line: Our decision on the report of Chief Enquirer Tarron is that the prisoner, Ian Chesterton, is guilty of murder and that his sentence is death. The said sentence to be administered three days after the end of this hearing, unless the representative for the accused can show positive proof why the execution should not be carried out. Will you stand up?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor stands.

Dialogue.Line: Representative for the defence, you have a grave duty. You have offered your services in this matter, which complies with the law of the city of Millenius, in that any person may speak on behalf of another. Are you acquainted with our laws?
Yes, I have studied some, my Lord.
Every latitude will be allowed to you, and if you are at fault, I will give you directions.
Thank you.
The representative of the court, Eyesen, has spoken his facts. You may now reply.
My Lords, I cannot defend a man when I have not considered every aspect of the case. I must have time to examine witnesses, read statements and to prepare my case.
I object most strongly.
The demand is reasonable in itself. The crime of murder in Millenius is in itself unusual. Then I grant you two days.
Thank you, my Lord.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The court rises.

Dialogue.Line: I congratulate you.
Thank you.
It will not alter the outcome.
We shall see.
Well done, Doctor.
I've been starting and studying their laws ever since I heard that Eprin had been murdered.
Eprin?
He was your friend?
Yes. You found him, Doctor?
Oh, yes, I had met him and arranged to take the micro-key, but something must have happened. That's why he tried to take the key earlier than we'd arranged.
And he was killed?
Yes. He must have told his plans to someone else and that someone else killed him and took the key.
Then all we have to do is find out who took the key and why.
In two days.

Yes, we shall need every minute of that. Now, we must all take a task on. Murder, I gather, is very rare here. Now, I want both of you to go to the library and find out all the case histories you can. Facts and figures.
Sentences.
And reasons for people being found not guilty.
Yes, yes, quite. Now, off you go, both of you, and meet me back here in three hours.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Altos and Sabetha leave.

Dialogue.Line: What can I do, Grandfather?
Well, you, my child, and Barbara, can be my detectives. And you, my friend.
Yes. What can I do, Doctor?
Trust me.
There was a mace beside the body, and there was blood on it. Chesterton was on the floor, unconscious. Either he slipped and bumped his head, or Eprin had got a blow in before he died.
And the key was gone, you say.

Yes, and that's the only element of the case I don't understand. My men did a heat reflector search of this room. It is absolutely certain that the micro-key isn't in here. It is equally certain that it's not been taken from here.
Oh, come now, Tarron. We're not dealing in magic, you know. It's obvious to me the key must have been taken from this room.
No. every person that came in here was checked by the autho-ray scanner as they went out. If anyone had the key on them, the scanner would have detected it.
Supposing the murderer hid the key on the body?
The body was searched. It wasn't there.
Then would you mind telling us what happened after the alarm bell went, please?

Well, the relief guard was the first to reach the outside of the door. He was joined almost immediately by the Controller and a Guardian who was on patrol outside. When I reached the door, it was opened and, well, you know what we found inside.
That's fantastic. It couldn't disappear into thin air.
Precisely, and I rather gather when we discover its location we shall also discover the real identity of the murderer.
But we know the murderer. It was Chesterton.
Mister Tarron, I wonder if you'd mind leaving us alone for a few moments. We'd like to discuss the aspects of this case.
Very well.
Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tarron leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, well, hmm.
Any ideas? Well?
What?
Have you any ideas how the key got out of here?
Oh, well, elementary, elementary.
Grandfather, do you mean you know? How? Where?
All in good time, my child. The important is I believe I know who did the killing.
But how? Tarron's been working on it all day. You've only been here a few minutes.
You see, Tarron never doubted that Chesterton was guilty. A grave error. Yes, a very grave error.
Yes, where as we know he's innocent.

Precisely. But someone did it, and we also know there was a third man in the room. How he got in here we shall know in a moment. Now let us assume he was hiding. Yes. Behind this door. Now, Barbara, you imagine that you are Chesterton for a moment. Come here. Now please, you look into the room, you see a body on the floor. What do you do?
I'd see if I could help.
I'll be the body.
Good. Right, now let me see you do it. There's a weapon beside the body. Do you examine it?
Yes, yes, I think I would.

Good. Then you look up in front of you and you see exactly what you came here for, the micro-key. Unbeknown to you, the third man comes out of hiding, creeps up behind you, and you are struck down, so. Now, he could take what he came here for. He opens the case, lifts the key, the alarm bell sounds. Now, he only has a few seconds so he conceals the key, runs to the door, opens it, gets out and then closes it. But he can't go any further because already the security guards and officials are on their way. So he decides to pretend that he is first on the scene!
The relief guard!
Yes.
Yes, of course. That's why the guard inside let him in in the first place. He knew him. He even expected him.
Yes, he went in, killed his colleague, heard Chesterton in the hall, hid behind the door and the rest we know.
That must be how it happened. I'll go and tell Tarron.
My dear child, this is only a theory. We must have proof.
But surely, if you know where the key is, that's proof.
If Tarron were to know that now, his case against Chesterton would be complete. I can't prove at this very moment that Chesterton didn't hide in its present location.
Oh. What do we do, then?
I have a little errand for you, and I think you will find it very, very interesting.
Oh. Please come in.
Thank you.
I'm afraid my husband isn't here at the moment. Do sit down.
I did want to talk to your husband. I thought there might be some facts he'd overlooked.
I'm sure he'd want to help, but he's already told you everything he knows.
Well, there might be some small thing, something he thought unimportant.
The Guardians are very thorough, you know. Anyway, he'd want the murderer to be caught. Eprin was a good friend of his. He wouldn't conceal anything.
No, of course not. Tell me, why would anyone want to steal the micro- key?
Because there are only five of them in the entire universe. It was brought to the city years ago by a man called Arbitan. It was the sworn duty of the Elders to protect it.
So they'd pay highly to recover it.
Yes, but you know all this. Why else would your friend steal it?
I had to go to the Guardian building again. They're asking questions about

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He sees Barbara and Susan sitting on the settee.

Dialogue.Line: You're one of the people with Chesterton. What are you doing here?
I want to talk to you.
I have nothing to say to you. Get out.
Ayden.
I don't want people prying into my affairs. Has she been asking questions about me?
Not as many as my Grandfather will ask when he calls you as a witness.
Get out! You heard me, get out!
I thought you might like to know that we know where the key is hidden.
Susan!

But you couldn't know where it is. I. Yes, yes, you know where it's hidden because Chesterton told you where he hid it. And now you're trying to throw suspicion on me. Well it won't work. Now get out before I
Before you what?
Kill us like you killed Eprin?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He raises his hand to hit Susan, but stops himself.

Dialogue.Line: You'd better go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara and Susan eavesdrop.

Dialogue.Line: What were they doing here?
Asking a few questions, nothing more.
What did she mean about the key?
I don't know what she meant, but you shouldn't have lost your temper like that. It was very foolish of you.
Don't you talk to me like that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It sounds like he has hit Kala very hard. Barbara tries to look through the keyhole as Ayden makes a telephonic communication. Then there are footsteps and they have to leave.

Dialogue.Line: Eyesen here.

Don't say any more, there are people near. I'll take it on the personal. All right, go ahead. (pause) You really think she knows something? (pause) You mean that our young friend might not be able to go through with it? (pause) Well listen carefully, and I'll tell you what you may have to do.

This mace, a weapon used in primitive times by vicious, savage, warmakers. The same savagery that wielded it then lives on in men like the accused. Members of the tribunal, the evidence already offered is more than enough to ensure the conviction of this man. But add to it the fact that under psychometric examination this mace was found to have been held in the right hand of the prisoner. I need say no more. That concludes the evidence for the prosecution.
We will now hear the statement from the representative of the accused and convicted.
My Lords, let me begin by saying that the murderer is without any doubt in this chamber. The trouble is, he's not under arrest, but my young friend here is.
But, can you substantiate this?
I can, my Lord. You will know his identity in a moment. I will now call my first witness. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sabetha gets up. The Doctor holds up a picture of a micro-key.

Dialogue.Line: This, my Lords, is a reproduction of the stolen micro-key. Do you recognise this, young lady?
Yes.
And do you know where it is now?
Yes, I do.
Then please tell the tribunal where its present location is.
It is here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And she holds up a micro-key, to general consternation.

Dialogue.Line: Where did you get it?
It was given to me by the man who killed the guard.
Is he here?
Yes.
Then please point him out to us.
There, sitting in the front row.
But she can't have found it. I

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He tries to make a run for it, but Barbara and Susan grab him.

Dialogue.Line: All right, I'll tell you everything. I'm not in this alone. They made me do it. I'll tell you

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There's a flash of light and he falls to the floor, dead. There's a stunned silence, then Kala drops to her knees next to him, sobbing.
Later, when the courtroom has been tidied up again.

Dialogue.Line: And so you see, my Lords, when Sabetha was showing the court the micro-key, it wasn't in actual fact the one that was stolen from the vault.
You say you have three of the micro-keys in your possession?
Yes, my Lord, and we returned to find the last one. Then they would all be returned to Arbitan.
The fact remains that the fourth key is missing.
Still in the place where it was hidden by the murderer Chesterton.
Oh, come now. Surely you don't think that he's still guilty? I admit that I resorted to a subterfuge when Sabetha accused Ayden of taking the key, but I think the results justifies the means.
There are a number of other points which we'd like to see cleared up.
Yes, my Lord.
First of all.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: We switch to another part of the courtroom.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, and I'm having psychometric tests made on the weapon that killed Ayden.
What exactly are these psychometric tests?
Its the science psychometry. Experts are able to divine from an object the characteristics of the person who last had contact with that object.
Well that sounds an improvement on fingerprints.
Fingerprints?
It's not important.
Whoever killed Ayden must have been implicated in the theft. Had he lived, he might have told us everything.
It was his wife I felt sorry for.
The doctors have given her oblivative drugs and sent her home to rest. She was hysterical. You'd better resume your places, the tribunal is about to start again.
Where's Susan?
She's gone to get Ian's statement.

It is clear that Aydon was involved in either the theft or the killing. It is also clear that he had an accomplice. Bearing in mind that the accused came here with the express purpose of recovering the micro-key, and remembering the evidence against him, his guilt becomes even more obvious. Will the prosecutor please summarise.

Despite the dramatics and hysterics of recent events, very little has changed. I submit that the accused did, by threat or coercion, involve Ayden in the murder and robbery. His last dying words were, they made me do it. They were the accused and his accomplices. They were standing near him when he was killed. One of them is responsible for his death.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: During this speech, a Guardian has whispered to Barbara, and she, Altos and Sabetha have got up and left.

Dialogue.Line: I submit that the defence has offered no new evidence, and the sentence of the tribunal should be carried out.

The tribunal concurs. Though it has deprived us of more detailed evidence, the unfortunate death of Guardian Ayden has surely not affected the issue. We will now hear a statement, a closing statement, from the defence.
I beg the indulgence of the tribunal, and ask for time to produce new evidence.
Denied. No purpose would be served in delaying these proceedings further. If you have nothing to add, the accused will be taken from here and executed in the prescribed manner.
What is it?
A messenger brought this for you.
Thank you.
I have to get back inside. Will you excuse me?
What is it?
It says, there will be another death if you disclose where the key is hidden.
What? Barbara, do you realise what this means? It proves that someone else was involved. We must tell Tarron and the Doctor, quickly.
Yes, but what does it mean, another death? Whose death?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The 'telephone' rings.

Dialogue.Line: Someone wishes to speak to you.
Hello?
I want to speak to Barbara Wright.
Susan?
Barbara, they made me call you.
Who, Susan? Who?
Barbara, listen
Susan? Susan? Are you there, Susan!
They're going to kill me.
Susan?
We must tell Tarron.
No.
Well, what else can we do? We've got to find her.
Yes, of course we have, but
You're thinking of the Doctor.

He mustn't know anything about this. He must keep his mind absolutely clear in order to concentrate on Ian. Anyway, how do we know that Tarron isn't implicated? Who'd suspect the Chief Investigator? He was next to Ayden in court when he was killed.
What do we do, Barbara?
We find Susan ourselves.
And remember, whoever is behind this kidnapping is either in league with the murderer, or is the murderer.
